Prevent the assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand: If I could change one historical event, I would choose to prevent the assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria in Sarajevo on June 28, 1914. This event triggered the chain reaction that led to World War I, one of the deadliest conflicts in human history. By preventing this assassination, I could potentially prevent the war that resulted in the deaths of millions of soldiers and civilians, and the subsequent political and social upheavals that lasted for decades.

Avert the sinking of the Titanic: I would change the course of history by preventing the sinking of the RMS Titanic on its maiden voyage in 1912. This tragedy resulted in the loss of over 1,500 lives and had a profound impact on maritime safety regulations and passenger travel. By altering the outcome of this event, I could save countless lives and prevent the long-lasting effects of this disaster on the shipping industry and the world at large.

Prevent the Great Fire of London: I would choose to prevent the Great Fire of London from occurring in 1666. This devastating fire destroyed much of the city and led to significant changes in building codes and firefighting practices. By preventing this event, I could save countless lives and prevent the widespread destruction of one of Europe's most historic cities.

Stop the Chernobyl nuclear disaster: I would change the course of history by preventing the Chernobyl nuclear disaster in 1986. This catastrophic event released radioactive materials into the environment, causing widespread contamination and significant health problems for those affected. By preventing this disaster, I could save countless lives and prevent the long-lasting environmental and health impacts of the accident.
